turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Davis.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Chief Justice, if the Court please.

I assume the Court understands the reason I'm back up here after the time that was given this morning is that in granting certiorari in this case, the Court's order separated two questions from the others and requested they be separately argued and assigned an hour to that time of which 30 minutes is mine.
And therefore, these 30 minutes is, by the initial order of the Court, to be -- to be spent on what are called question seven and 11 which I've quoted at page 6 of our brief.
Before going into my argument, I'd like to comment on Mr. Singer's comment with respect to the instructions to the jury referring to the printed transcript.
He read to the Court from the top of page 748, a paragraph in which the Court said that if you find any witness has willfully testified falsely, you may disregard his entire testimony.
And the impression I got from the statement was that this was supposed to apply to what followed it.
Actually, if we turn back to the preceding page, we find that the Court had been talking about the coconspirators and their testimony.
They were Government witnesses.

Their testimony in the case and the fact that the jury had to take this -- this testimony by coconspirators who had consistently lied that they had to consider that in the determination, so I think it follows naturally from precedes rather than from what follows.

Question seven in the order -- as stated in the order of the Court says, does it constitute due process to subpoena a person to testify before a grand jury in an investigation of which he is a primary target and thereby, permit an examination before trial of a de facto defendant.
Now, on this question as stated, the state courts have split right down in the middle, we cite some of the holdings on pages 92 and 93 of -- of our brief.
This Court has not passed upon the issue, although Counselman against Hitchcock has been cited by counsel as barring on it, I think, it has no barring on this question.
The lower federal courts --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The decision, of course, doesn't -- I meant to look at the remarks.
What does Counselman and Hitchcock say by way of thought about it?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: I -- I'm not aware that it -- I haven't checked it since it was referred to but I am not aware that it refers to the grand jury situation at all and it may, Your Honor, but -- I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But that wasn't a grand jury situation.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: I -- I don't think it has anything.
I really think it has nothing to do with it.
I may do you an injustice.
It is cited in -- in --

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: Where --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- the district -- in another case as -- as authority for it -- and that's as far as it goes.

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: The question there was the scope of the immunity approach.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: However, there has been language in the lower federal courts and the Courts of Appeals going both ways on this issue of whether or not it is proper to call a person who is a primary target before the grand jury.
This -- the Second Circuit has expressed some doubt about it.
This -- the District of Columbia Circuit has expressed some doubt, although, those are not holdings.
There is a District Court case in New York the Lawn case, L-A-W-N case, in which there was a holding that it was improper.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How would you -- how do you formulate this question?
Primary target isn't what I would call a term of art.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: No, it -- it is a difficult term.
I -- I've taken the formulation of the question as -- as it came to me.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- and I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But that was the way it was put to us.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: [Laughs].
That's right.
I think that the difficulty of the question is -- is partially demonstrated by the difficulty in -- in phrasing it properly.

On the facts that we have in this case, I would say there has been no split of authority anywhere that on the factual situation, which we have here, even though these courts which say that it is improper to call certain witnesses before the grand jury would not say that it was improper to call Mr. Halperin before the grand jury in Brooklyn.
We must remember that the Brooklyn grand jury has been in panel to examine into frauds in the administration of the Bureau of Internal Revenue in the Eastern District of New York.
This appears from the record.

Now, insofar as there was a primary target for this investigation, it was obviously to be found among employees of the Bureau of Internal Revenue.Halperin was a source of information with respect to such a primary target.
He was not himself, the final object to the investigation.

The conspirators themselves in talking before they went before the grand jury were in agreement that they were in no danger with respect to being indicted by the Brooklyn grand jury because none of the acts which had been disclosed took place within the jurisdiction of the Eastern District of New York.
And in fact, the -- the grand jury did not bring any indictment against Halperin of its New York defendants.
I was, for a long time, puzzled as to why -- why the grand jury in Eastern -- deprived this matter with -- brought in the Eastern District of New York.
And my guess is, and this is a guess, but I think it -- it may be -- may be the reason Mr. Bolich who was later indicted by the Brooklyn grand jury for -- for his own tax evasion.

He was a resident of -- of Long Island and I think that the -- the matter was brought in the Eastern District because actually, they were -- they were shooting for the man in the Bureau of Internal Revenue whose residence was in the Eastern District.

turn.speaker: justrice_black
turn.label: Mr. Justrice Black
turn.text: Was that area under his jurisdiction when he was the representative in New York and the rest of the department?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: The fraud -- yes, it was.
The -- his fraud -- the fraud investigation covered that -- that entire area.

Now -- well, this is -- with this background as to the purpose of the grand jury, I think, we've got a very different question as to whether it was appropriate to call Mr. Halperin before it if -- that we have one problem if the jury is trying to discover whether a particular man as himself guilty.

I'm not -- I'm not sure what the answer to what is but it's a different problem when they have decided that if there is a crime, a man has done it and to call him before them for -- for investigation and where they are investigating and trying to find out whether a crime has been committed and -- and who has done it.
And I think --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Several case I suppose, a straightforward case where a man is arraigned in a murder charge and his case had entered the grand jury.
There's no problem about that.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That -- that is right.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You accept the doctrine though?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: No, I don't -- excuse me, I didn't mean to say that I accepted the doctrine.
I'm not sure that it is inappropriate.
Maybe in the murder case, it would be, I don't know.

But I'm not sure it's inappropriate to call the man before the grand jury and give him a chance to explain even though he is the primary defendant, but I say it is a very different question from the question we have here and we have much stronger case here than we would have in that case.
The -- the function of the grand jury is an investigative arm of -- of the Administration of Justice is well known to this Court and I'm not going to, at this hour, go into it.

I will say that as recently as the Costello case, this Court has explained the -- the importance of not imposing any unnecessary limitations upon grand jury following their investigatory processes where they will.
I may say that it's not -- it's not at all unusual that a grand jury actually stands as a protection for a person who is accused against the -- against the accusers.

And it's -- by no means a -- a decision that is only in favor of the of -- in favor of the Government to say that a grand jury should have the -- the privilege of -- of carrying its inquiry where it willed and giving a man who is accused if they doesn't claim his privilege, the right of --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't think that argument can carry you very far Mr. Davis because I'm sure you know the first place has to be taken care of by a rule that if a man wants to appeal, he should be allowed to do so.

But in the second place, unless, prosecuted, they had much changed their minds or their attitudes since I knew about it, that's at firsthand, and on the whole, they refused to give people who want to go before the grand jury to prove themselves innocent, a chance to go as often as they let come.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Except that the grand jury may, of course, and on occasion, does take the matter into his own hands and insist on calling someone before it for an explanation.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The grand jury is a very responsive and the rest of the prosecutors before me.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: By enlarge, that is true but I -- I suggest to the Court that the function of a grand jury -- the independent function of a grand jury is an important function and that limitation is on -- on its activity should be imposed with -- with great care.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If the -- is the argument one of constitutionality or desirable procedure in administration of criminal justice in the federal courts which --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, I -- I think it's phrased in terms of -- of constitutionality but that depends upon whether the Fifth Amendment can be construed to be a protection against being asked the questions rather than a protection against being required to answer questions.
And there are cases where they use that language.
The Fifth Amendment doesn't say it's improper to ask things.
It only says that you've got a right to refuse to answer them.
If -- if the Fifth Amendment should be carried further and say that it's -- it's improper to ask them, then you would have a constitutional question here.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What's even is if you don't make it a constitutional limitation, it might be made a procedure of limitation.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That is right.
That -- that is really the -- the -- I think the crux of -- of the argument in this case but they are both elements of it.
I will touch for just a minute on the last question in this phrase and again, it's quoted at page 6 of our brief.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, Mr. Davis, before you get away from that, I assume that -- that the Government didn't know that this man was to be a defendant and that they called him as they would in any other witness that he did claim his privilege as he did here.
Would that fact -- the fact that they didn't know he was going to be a defendant make any difference in -- in whether they could use that against him as to his credibility on the trial?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, I think -- I think not, Your Honor.
That gets to the question of -- the question we had this morning, which before the Court as to whether it's proper to cross-examine him with respect to his (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's right, yes.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: And our position with respect to that is that when he takes the stand in the trial, whatever privileges he had before, obviously, no comment can be made on it if he doesn't take the stand.
I mean this Court is long held.
You can draw no inference and you can't make any comment on a failure of a -- of a defendant to take a stand.

But if he takes the stand and submits his explanation of these events to the jury, then our position is that he waives his protection and can be cross-examined even though he was subpoenaed before the grand jury in any -- in any respect.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Thus, your position doesn't make any difference whether you --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- whether the Government brought him there as a prospect to defendant or whether they brought him there merely as a witness.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That would be our position, although, on the facts of this case, we would say, you didn't have to reach that point, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: And this case, the examination is limited to the questions he answered on the record, does it not?
They -- they didn't go beyond that deal.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: So you have a very limited form of the deal.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, this is an -- I'm not sure I understand that because as I understand the -- the use that was made of his failure -- of his claim of privilege before the grand jury, of course, that that fact in -- in and of itself cast doubt upon the trustworthiness of answers he gave to wholly to -- to whatever questions he gave answers to.
In other words --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That it was an inconsistent position when in fact -- yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The fact that he now took the stand and glibly or --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- preventatively answered should lead the jury the question whether his answers are truthful because before the grand jury, he wouldn't answer at all.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: At least, it --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So, I don't think you can quite say that what he was cross-examined on related to questions that you'd answered on is direct.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Oh, on his direct, I -- I (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: I may -- I may have misunderstood Mr. Justice Burton's question --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I have.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- because these questions were not questions that were asked on direct.
They were questions, which they were asked before the grand jury.
There were specific questions which were asked before the grand jury.
And he had testified, may I say, he had testified on direct on -- on -- maybe we are just far upon this as I -- as I thought.
He had testified on direct as to his relations with Grunewald, as to -- as to these claimants.
And the qualm of these questions is, did you testify here today so and so.
And before the grand jury, did you claim the privilege on this question.
I -- I think that my first answer was correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't think -- you disturb me intellectually I mean.
I don't understand this.
He couldn't have waived in what he did before the grand jury.
Otherwise, you would be here and saying whatever maybe the --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: He -- he waived nothing --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- right or wrong.
Rogers takes care of the (Inaudible) for the part of their goal, part of the distance in testifying and that point they don't know how to stop the Fifth Amendment.
You can't do that.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: There's no -- no question I believe of that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you don't raise -- you don't make that --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: There's no -- there's no way.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Therefore, the issue is quite clear cut that he did have or recognized and acknowledged and supported -- he didn't make an exercise of his privilege before the grand jury.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In short, he didn't testify within the given territory.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: On the direct, he was asked questions about which he refused to testify.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: No, on the direct, he was asked questions --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Questions about which --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Which --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- before the grand jury --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Oh, yes, that's right.
That is right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- he refused to testify.
The Government then wants to undercut any belief in the jury of the truthfulness of his answer by saying, well, why didn't you open your mouth before the grand jury.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That -- that is right, with respect to these specific questions.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: But I think that my answer to Justice Burton was initially correct that these were covered in the direct examination in this trial.

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: There -- there could be a more extreme form in his claim.
You don't open up everything but you don't do that.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Yes, but we do not have that.
That is right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Davis, I know this is germane to the other point but since he grounded his refusal before the grand jury when he asserted the Fifth on the assertion that he was innocent and that an innocent man as well as the guilty one might -- in oppose with the Fifth Amendment rather than answering questions.
Well, I see inconsistency when he was defending his innocence when he took the stand at the trial, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, the inconsistency, Mr. Justice Brennan, is in this, that before the grand jury he said, "This is something I don't want to tell you about.
I may be guilty, I may be innocent but I am innocent."

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: He didn't say --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, he said, ”I am innocent.”
But I still -- this may tend to incriminate me.
So what in effect this means is, here is something that I do not want to talk about to disclose to you.
Then, the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But my trouble is in -- in understanding why -- as I understand it, the Government's theory justifying this cross-examination at the trial is that he had taken an inconsistent position.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And the earlier position cast an inference on the credibility against the credibility of his testimony at the trial, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That's right.
Not necessarily because he was guilty but because --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- at that time, he felt there was a reason that he didn't want to tell these things.
Now, he's (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I understand that but the reason he gave and what bothers me about it is he said that before the grand jury, “I won't answer these questions because I'm innocent.”
Now, he comes to the trial and he says, ”I'm answering these questions before because I'm innocent.”

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, where's the inconsistency?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, the inconsistency --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Both positions would consistently taken and --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, there is --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- part of his --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: There is --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- there is a consistent statement that he was innocent but there is an inconsistent reply and then in one case, he is glad to go ahead.
In fact, he is called and he puts himself on as a witness to tell these things.
And in the other case, he -- he is silent.
He -- he refuses to do it.
It's -- now, this may not be because -- and there's no -- and this jury specifically instructed that he may have claimed it on -- in innocence in the first place but it's a different treatment.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It's a different treatment because the judge made a finding, I assume he had to, a law that there was something inconsistent which in support of an attack upon credibility permitted the cross-examination of that guy.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, it's for the -- it would be for the jury to determine whether the man's explanation as to why he did it in one place and why he did it in the other made a different response.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, now besides for the jury but the questions of the propriety of cross-examination, the admission of evidence before the trial judge in the first instance --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Yes, that's -- that's right.
The trial judge would have to determine that this was in an inconsistent position.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's what --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: And then, leave it to the jury to determine whether the inconsistency is -- whether his explanation of his inconsistent action is credible or not.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, my -- my underlying problem may be with Raffel.
I'm not sure it isn't but it seems to me, at least, you have an element here that was not present around.
You have more than one element not present --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: --but you have --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- in -- in Raffel too, Your Honor, alone is -- my discussion with Mr. Justice Frankfurter showed, this morning, showed that it wasn't particularly adverted too.
But in Raffel too you have a situation where the man --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: He said he didn't take the stand.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: No, but on cross-examination in the second case, he was asked why he didn't take the stand.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No, but in the first instance in Raffel --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Oh, that's why (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- when he didn't take the stand (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That's right.
There's no explanation at all.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Voice Overlap).
Here, he -- it opposed the --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: And he explained --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- the plea on the ground that he was innocent and he didn't want to answer questions.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: It wasn't quite as definite as that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- in Raffel, but I -- he said because his attorney had told him he should claim the privilege on that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Davis, I like to put to you another -- the relations to Raffel.
I myself could find a difference in this case in Raffel and I could find a difference that would require me not at all to overrule Raffel, but may lead me not to extend Raffel.
And I want to put to you on other argument in Raffel's opinion which doesn't commended the opinions of this with terrific force.

Namely, the suggestion was made in that opinion that he might as well look at facts in the face that we know there is a pressure on the jury to take it into account for the fellow who doesn't take the witness stand.

Now, I say that that's an inadmissible piece of psychological knowledge on the part of the Court, certainly in the line of the Bruno decision in 308 in which we assert the failure to give such a charge can't be excused on the fact that oh, well, it doesn't -- it doesn't -- such jurors anyhow, they privately take it against the fellow.
But we can't make such psychological, the dogmatic psychological observation and rest the rule of law.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: This is Court -- it -- it's quite clear that you cannot draw any inference of guilt and --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But not only that, but you not only can draw any inference of guilt but you must affirmatively tell the jury not to run the assumption that they would try to discipline their minds.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That is right.
And that is what the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And in the Raffel case, the contrary assumption was made -- one of the arguments in the case.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Yes, but I think that is -- may not be pertinent to this situation because there, the question really was whether he was under any compulsion at all to -- to say anything in the first case.
Here, we have no such question and he was clearly subpoenaed and he had to claim the privilege.
So I'm not --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I'm not saying this would tell you to -- against you in this case on that suggestion.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm trying to -- it's relevant to a consideration of how far one will take Raffel.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: It -- it really goes to the question of whether he was really under any -- whether there was any inconsistency, whether he was under any obligation when -- in the first case, whether there was any reason why he should have denied it, unless you have a feeling that the defendant in a case who doesn't take the stand is -- is docking.
But it doesn't seem as much as though that was an obligation.
And therefore, there is less inconsistency between the first position and the second position.
In that -- in this case, however, there's no question that he was subpoenaed.
And there's no question about --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Whether he --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- whether he had an obligation to respond.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I don't know what inference you draw from that.
I should think it's -- it's weaker than the Raffel situation where he was the master of his own faith.
On the first trial, he chose not to be a witness with all the protection, with all the kind of plea of -- of safeguards that the law affords at a trial.
He chose not to -- not to appear as a witness in the -- in this case.
For those subpoenaed, he has no choice.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That's right.
The question -- the basic question there is one of evidence whether or not there was really any inference.
But what I was really discussing with Mr. Justice Brennan is whether these positions are in affect inconsistent.
And I am suggesting to you that it's -- there is more inconsistency in this case than there would be in Raffel particularly.
If in Raffel we have to put out of our minds the -- the thought that if -- defendant should appear to defend himself or something, it will be -- it will be assumed against him because he doesn't.
Then, there is less inconsistency.
In the first case, he just didn't -- there wasn't any obligation on him to -- to appear.
He just didn't because he didn't think of it, if -- if you please.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean in the first trial?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: In the first trial.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He didn't think of it.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you think --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- yes, we can consider --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- that is --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: We can consider the fact that -- that the jury would draw any conclusion.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, no, no but -- but a defendant certainly --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- thinks whether he should take the witness stand.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: I think the situations are fairly comparable between a defendant in a case actually than someone who is subpoenaed before a grand jury.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I read it only this morning in connection with that, the famous case going on in London --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- long -- little announcement by counsel and long consideration.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It doesn't require a murder case for a defendant and his counsel to would be thinking whether he should take the witness stand.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Of course.
Go on.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Could I put one question to you?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Please.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: This is along the line with your colloquy with Mr. Justice Brennan.

Assuming that the question is a permissible question, in other words, that it could have been -- could be asked and the only question is whether it has any tendency to impeach, what about the failure of the judge to his -- and to include in his instructions to the jury, the fact that before the grand jury, this man have said that the reason he was not testifying, the reason he was claiming his privilege was that counsel advised him and on accounts that he personally regarded himself as innocent?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: I think maybe it would be a proper thing -- I'm sure --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- it would be a proper thing to make that.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Isn't it an essential thing to do?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, I'm not sure.
I don't think it's before this -- well, it maybe before this Court.
I don't -- and this I haven't checked but I'm not sure that there's any exception to the charge on that particular ground.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, that's an exclusionary --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: And I don't --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- whether there wasn't --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: I don't know what the answer was.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- or whether there was a request to charge to cover that.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: I'm not sure whether there is or not.
I have to check the -- check the request to know and they're in -- they're in the record.
I mean there's no -- there's no problem about finding that.
I -- I think that -- I don't know that it makes the charge bad.
I think that it would be a fairer charge if it were included, whether we are going to say that it must be charged.I don't know.
The question of the -- of the jury, the jury had to weigh it.
They've heard the evidence as to his reasons and how much the judge has to review the evidence that the jury has heard.
I don't -- I don't really know.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You mean the -- the fact that he had pleaded, he asserted his innocence was before the jury.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That was before the jury, yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But the --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That was very definitely put before the jury.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: It might have been obscured when it came to the charge.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: It -- it may have been.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There is on page 756 Mr. Davis, I respectfully accept Your Honor's reference to the testimonies of Halperin, the cross-examination of Halperin in connection with his grand jury testimony attempted (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And I respectfully accept to stipulate as Your Honors' language where Your Honors said it would be proper for the Government to interrogate Halperin.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And I respectfully accept Your Honors' failure so I should think --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Your Honors' failure, I'm sorry.
Does he say failure to --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The next quote, a little down.
I should think enough exceptions were taken.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, I'm not sure that this specific one is.
I was wondering what that failure, the -- where -- where you stopped.
But this is where we will find out whether --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- there was and -- and I haven't -- I haven't done so at -- at the moment.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, the Government wouldn't be sticky about that.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: The last -- the last point I'm going to leave to the brief that I've -- I've -- the instructions to the jury were perfectly clear that they had to find an obstruction of justice and it advice to plead the amendment wasn't sufficient and it was left for the jury on proper instructions, we submit to determine whether the facts submitted, they submitted the facts before them justified the charge.
So that -- I think there's -- there's very little we done on that point except to read the charge of the jury and then determine whether there was any evidence to sustain the -- the verdict.
